snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of newly remodeled Savoy restaurant in SoHo; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: A restaurant as tiny as the Savoy doesn't seem as if it could subdivide, but it has. After nearly 13 years the restaurant has shed its Garbo-like image of secrecy, transforming the ground floor into a modern-looking cafe with diner overtones. The upstairs bar has been moved downstairs, the entrance to the restaurant has been shifted northward to the corner of Prince and Crosby Streets, and huge windows now make the Savoy's interior almost shockingly visible to the outside world. The upstairs remains old-fashioned and intimate. The brick fireplace survives intact.
abstract: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of newly remodeled Savoy restaurant in SoHo; photo (S)

lead_paragraph: Q. I often see question marks instead of text on Web pages that use Cyrillic or Arabic alphabets or the character sets of East Asian languages. Is there a way to read these Web pages in their native languages?
abstract: Q. I often see question marks instead of text on Web pages that use Cyrillic or Arabic alphabets or the character sets of East Asian languages. Is there a way to read these Web pages in their native languages?    A. Reading Web pages that use non-Latin alphabets is a lot easier than it used to be, thanks to improvements in browser software and computer operating systems. Most modern Web browsers, like Microsoft Internet Explorer and Apple Computer's new Safari program, can easily handle the foreign alphabets. If you are using an older browser, updating your software might help.

lead_paragraph: TO say that Dr. Michael Bruno, a specialist in cosmetic and reconstructive dentistry, is a perfectionist is to vastly underplay his world view. Dr. Bruno, who lives with his wife, the shoe designer Bettye Muller, in a rigorously designed white lacquer apartment that is uncannily suggestive of a perfect set of new teeth, is driven by the inspiration of three adjectives: efficient, streamlined and continuous, according to Ms. Muller, who has written them down in a notebook.

I'm especially drawn to sweet wines in the holiday season, when a glass poured after a meal with some good cheese can add just the right festive touch.

lead_paragraph: MIDWAY between storefront pasta and pizza parlors and palatial Italian restaurants with waiters with tuxedos, piano players and wine that starts at $30 a bottle lies Tutto Fresco. This solid, middle-of-the-road Italian, buried behind a Burger King, up a little hill, at the end of a shopping center that runs perpendicular to Glen Street in Glen Cove, is easy to miss. But it's precisely the kind of restaurant many diners are looking for.

lead_paragraph: WHEN Forbes magazine splashed a marijuana leaf on its cover last month, John Buffalo Mailer weighed the propriety of flaunting such images in public. Mr. Mailer, who is just starting out in journalism, said he hoped never to run such a cover. ''It's a personal thing, but I don't believe we should be throwing that in people's faces,'' he said. ''I don't think that's our role.''

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Laguna Beach, Calif; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: FOX'S ''The O.C.'' may make all of Orange County look like a vast and arrogant suburb by the sea, but there are still idyllic islands amid the sprawl and bulldozed billion-dollar hillsides. The county's crown jewel is tiny Laguna Beach, set on striking verdant slopes that plunge to the Pacific. Laguna, which started as an artists' colony in the early 1900's, has long been expensive, but the recently opened Montage Resort & Spa, with 262 rooms that start at $450 a night, has upped the luxury quotient considerably. Still, surfers, artists and a large cast of resident eccentrics give Laguna a bohemian edge. CHRIS DIXON
abstract: Article on 36-hour visit to Laguna Beach, Calif; photos; maps (M)

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Charlotte, NC; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: OVER the last 20 years, Charlotte, North Carolina's biggest city, has remade itself from a textiles town into an investment and banking center, the nation's second-largest financial-services hub after New York City (and about to become bigger if the proposed merger of Bank of America and Fleet goes through). The moderate Carolina weather makes the city a pleasant place to stroll in winter, while museums and hip shops are also a draw. And though the city has a thriving historic-preservation movement, you get the unmistakable feeling that Charlotte sees itself as a city of the future -- and it has the new skyscrapers to prove it. LOUIS JACOBSON

snippet: Clive Thompson surveys some futuristic gadgets for kitchen; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: More than any other room in the house, the kitchen is the place to find futuristic gadgets. In 1803, the inventor Moses Coates patented a newfangled device called an ''apple parer'' -- the highest of high-tech back then. The blender came along in 1922, the Cuisinart in 1973; Philippe Starck introduced his famous U.F.O.-shaped juicer in 1990. So what's the next wave of kitchen tools? We've selected six concepts, dreamed up by some of the country's most innovative designers. They are by turns whimsical, technical and brilliant -- and although none of these objects actually exist yet, in physical form, consider these designs as snapshots from a future kitchen.

lead_paragraph: American manufacturing activity rose to its highest level in nearly 20 years last month as factories raced to keep up with demand and indicated a readiness to expand their work forces for the first time in three years, according to a survey published on Monday.
abstract: American manufacturing activity rose to its highest level in nearly 20 years last month as factories raced to keep up with demand and indicated a readiness to expand their work forces for the first time in three years, according to a survey published on Monday.     In the latest good economic news, the Institute of Supply Management reported that its November survey of purchasing managers showed a surge in new orders and a big jump in production in almost every industry. The institute said its overall index of manufacturing activity climbed to the highest level since December 1983, an increase much greater than most economists expected.

snippet: Public Lives profile of Victor L Robles, former New York City councilman, now city clerk; office oversees marriage licenses and other records; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: LOVE and marriage never did perform a horse-and-carriage dovetail for New York's city clerk, Victor L. Robles, whose office opposite City Hall churns out 70,000 marriage licenses each year and is host to 40,000 nuptials in its revamped chapels of love. He is divorced and shuns remarriage despite being surrounded by starry-eyed couples who haunt the hallway outside his office waiting to be hitched officially. ''I'm a bachelor now and I intend to stay that way until the day I die,'' he states, his cuff links and golden apple tie tack twinkling.

snippet: Karla Cook reviews Sergeantsville Inn restaurant in Sergeantsville, NJ; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN an asterisk denotes vegetarian and there's only one asterisk on the menu I know I'm in meat country. At the Sergeantsville Inn, however, it's not the regular lineup of steak, pork, chicken and seafood. It's Kobe beef, Beluga caviar, ostrich, boar and elk. This is Hungry Man food in black tie, with crisp white tablecloths and sparkling candlelight against rough stone walls that have stood since the 1700's and have housed, through the years, an ice house, a grocery store, an ice cream parlor and a pelt trading center. This is the land of big white plates and sumo-size portions of meat and carbs to match, with a long list of exotic martinis, doubtless there to help all that food go down.

lead_paragraph: Mobility Aid for Disabled
abstract: Mobility Aid for Disabled    Q. Is it possible to rent (or, if necessary, buy) an electric transporter in Guadalajara for my wife, who cannot walk much since a stroke? -- Raymond Kenyon, Murfreesboro, Tenn.    A. The Mexican Tourism Board, (800) 446-3942, www.visitmexico.com, was unable to find a medical-equipment supplier that rents motorized wheelchairs or scooters. It said electric wheelchairs are sold at Ortiz Productos Médicos Ortopédicos y de Rehabilitación, Calle Galeana 239, Colonia Centro, Guadalajara, telephone (33) 3613-1460, for about $2,375, at 10.7 pesos to the dollar.

lead_paragraph: AMERICANS don't cotton to elegant dry wines, we are told, because we are raised on Coca-Cola and sugar-coated everything else. But the truth is, in a guilty sort of way, we still love our sweet wines. Only now we call them dessert wines.

lead_paragraph: AS the seasons change, it's out with flip-flops and in with sturdy oxfords. Out with tick checks; in with scarves. Out with strawberries, cherries and sunflowers; in with apples, pears and parsnips. And, finally, out with frozen lemonade on the boardwalk, and in with soups. Not just any soups -- but fragrant, simmered-all-day soups, with rich stocks that start with a triumvirate of bones, aromatics and thyme, the soups with aromas and flavors that can turn a house into a home, or a restaurant into a destination.

lead_paragraph: THE Cajun craze that Paul Prudhomme started nearly 20 years ago had unfortunate results. It redrew the map of southern cooking, making Louisiana look twice as big as Alabama, Mississippi and the Carolinas put together. It also created the completely false impression that New Orleans is Cajun, but that's another story. The principal damage, besides nearly exterminating the redfish, was to marginalize the great, mainstream tradition of southern cooking.

snippet: Mark Bittman reports on various segments of dining scene in Los Angeles: glitzy establishments serving California fusion food, ethnic restaurants and smaller number of impressive, upscale restaurants that are true destinations; photos (L)
lead_paragraph: THE dining scene in Los Angeles is dominated by two categories of restaurant. The first is a group of glitzy establishments serving fusion food of a sort known as California cuisine. A few practitioners of this style have made names for themselves, Wolfgang Puck and Michael McCarty most notably -- and justifiably. But most cannot compare to them, and their food, beginning with tuna tartare and ending with warm, undercooked chocolate cake, exhibits the forced, bland hipness for which so many American restaurants are derided.

snippet: William Grimes reviews restaurant Atelier in Midtown Manhattan; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: AS a general rule, the better the restaurant, the longer it takes to hit its stride. When the place has lofty ambitions, as Atelier does, the general rule becomes an iron law. What is a critic to do? Common sense says to wait, say, six months before writing a review. Let the chef and the rest of the team find their footing. In the real world, however, common sense is nonsense. Readers cannot wait indefinitely, forks at the ready, to get the lowdown on an important new restaurant. The critic's job is to get a review to the table while it's still hot.

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Sarasota, Fla; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: IN the great war between nature and culture, it can be hard to satisfy both those family members who want museums and those who want beach. For that matter, it is often difficult to satisfy those warring parts of yourself that want, variously, edification and relaxation. In Sarasota, the beachfront city promoted by the circus impresario John Ringling in the 1920's, you can have a little of each. Respected cultural institutions on the mainland coexist with vibrant beach, golf and tennis options on the barrier islands of Lido Key, Longboat Key and Siesta Key, all three just a short causeway away. ANNE GLUSKER

lead_paragraph: Forbidden files are circulating on the Internet and threats of lawsuits are in the air. Music trading? No, it is the growing controversy over one company's electronic voting systems, and the issues being raised, some legal scholars say, are as fundamental as the sanctity of elections and the right to free speech.

abstract: EVENTS    AFRICAN DIASPORA FILM FESTIVAL 2003. With screenings, discussions and other events through Dec. 14. Screenings this weekend include ''Clay Dolls,'' directed by Nouri Bouzid, tonight at 7:20; ''French Wedding Caribbean Style,'' directed by Julius Amedee Laou, tonight at 9:30 and Sunday night at 10; ''Soldiers of the Rock,'' directed by Norman Maake, tomorrow night at 7:45; and ''One Love,'' directed by Rick Elgood, tomorrow night at 9:50. Most screenings are at Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, Lower East Side. Screening tickets are $8.50; students and 62+, $6. Panel discussions and other events are planned at Teachers College, Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street, Morningside Heights, and the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, Lenox Avenue and 135th Street, Harlem. Other events range from $6 for individual panels to $110 for all events. Information: (212) 864-1760; www.nyadff.org.

lead_paragraph: Q. My old laptop works fine, but its battery can barely hold a charge. Is it possible to upgrade to one of the newer batteries, like lithium ion, that are supposed to last longer between charges?
abstract: Q. My old laptop works fine, but its battery can barely hold a charge. Is it possible to upgrade to one of the newer batteries, like lithium ion, that are supposed to last longer between charges?    A. Over the years several types of batteries have been used to power laptop computers, including nickel cadmium (NiCad), nickel metal hydride (NiMH) and lithium ion (Li-Ion). Nickel cadmium batteries are prone to develop memory problems over time: the battery must be completely drained and totally recharged for it to hold a charge. These battery types are not generally interchangeable because the chemistry of each is distinct.

lead_paragraph: New York has no official Little Middle East, but the two blocks of Steinway Street between 28th Avenue and Astoria Boulevard in Queens come close. Yemeni, Moroccans, Egyptians and other Arab immigrants live, work and shop along this strip. Bookstores such as IPCI (International Publications of Islamic Culture) sell copies of the Koran, and the windows of delis are lined with big, green cans of ghee, the clarified butter popular in Middle Eastern cuisine. The signs for the barber, the tailor and the dentist are all in Arabic. At Laziza (Arabic for ''delicious'') Bakery, the favorite is savory, sweet kanafa, a Palestinian dessert of pomegranate juice and white cheese atop thin pastry.

snippet: The most astonishing thing about this film — a comedy that would have to work harder to even justify the appellation uninspired — is that a kick in the groin is now a joke for toddlers. They are both the target audience and the co-stars of this Ed...
lead_paragraph: The most astonishing thing about ''Daddy Day Care,'' a comedy that would have to work harder even to justify the appellation uninspired, is that a kick in the groin is now a joke for toddlers. They are both the target audience and the co-stars of this Eddie Murphy vehicle -- more of a Big Wheel, really.
abstract: The most astonishing thing about this film — a comedy that would have to work harder to even justify the appellation uninspired — is that a kick in the groin is now a joke for toddlers. They are both the target audience and the co-stars of this Eddie Murphy vehicle — more of a Big Wheel, really. In "Daddy Day Care," intended for those who take their apple juice in sipping cups, Mr. Murphy is an out-of-work marketing executive with no real interest in kids outside his own son. He decides to open a day-care center with Phil (Jeff Garlin), his pal and equally fired colleague, who's a little afraid of his own son. The extremely flimsy connective tissue is Mr. Murphy, who barely bothers to do takes; he'll raise an eyebrow here and there, but he mostly uses a voice so smooth and warm, you could pour it over pancakes. And in this context — in which the very young audience is so primed to react to him as Eddie Murphy, it's surprising the kids in the cast don't call him Eddie — he can get away with it, because he knows that the movie will do most of the work for him; he's Beverly Hills Pop. You can't get more high concept, or less plotted, that this, and "Daddy Day Care" is proof — it's a series of trailers for Nickelodeon, most of which feature Mr. Garlin getting attacked by something angry, either kids or bees, and, probably in the sequel, kids of bees. — Elvis Mitchell

snippet: Craig Kellogg article pays tribute to Design Research, whose late founder Benjamin Thompson developed concept of selling contemporary designs in clothing and home goods under one roof; Harvard Square flagship store in Cambridge, Mass, open from 19...
lead_paragraph: For the sort of person who cared desperately about icy Iittala highball glasses or Alvar Aalto serving trolleys, Design Research was, from 1953 to 1978, home away from home. Ray Eames shopped at the Design Research branch in Beverly Hills, as did Rudi Gernreich. Julia Child preferred the retailer's Harvard Square flagship store in Cambridge, Mass., where she borrowed imported cookware for her television series ''The French Chef.'' And Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis is said to have discovered her first Marimekko dress at Design Research in Hyannis, Mass., one summer. (Ultimately she collected at least eight.)
abstract: Craig Kellogg article pays tribute to Design Research, whose late founder Benjamin Thompson developed concept of selling contemporary designs in clothing and home goods under one roof; Harvard Square flagship store in Cambridge, Mass, open from 1953 to 1978, had open, multilevel interior and featured bold, eclectic displays that presaged Pottery Barn and Crate & Barrel; photos; Thompson, who lost entire investment in 1978 bankruptcy, went on to design Faneuil Hall Marketplace in Boston and South Street Seaport in New York (special section, Home Design) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Madison, Wis; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: ON an isthmus sandwiched by Lakes Mendota and Monona, Madison, the capital of Wisconsin, is a progressive university town noted for the good life: sailing, paddling and windsurfing in the summer; cross-country skiing, hiking and ice-skating in the winter (which can be so cold, in fact, that bundled-up Madisonians take on a unisex look); good old Midwestern values all year-round. In 1948, Life magazine featured Madison as its pick for the best place to live in America; thankfully, not much has changed. It's the kind of place where you will find well-maintained (and well-used) bike paths, an abundance of locally grown organic food at the weekend farmers' market and bed-and-breakfasts with ecological and historical awareness. But don't let Madison's fresh-scrubbed face fool you -- its radical 1960's past may have mellowed into more of a fervor for football, but it is all balanced with a sophisticated cultural life comparable to that of a much larger city. Frank Lloyd Wright buildings dot the landscape, and thriving theater and arts communities can be found on and off campus, along with a competitive culinary scene and a diverse population that includes punk-rock students and die-hard conservatives. What could be finer? BONNIE TSUI
abstract: Article on 36-hour visit to Madison, Wis; photos; maps (M)

abstract: Denise Paige Gordon and Dr. Edgard Said El Chaar were married on Wednesday at Notre Dame des Victoires Roman Catholic Church in San Francisco. The Rev. Gary R. Thomas performed the ceremony.    Mrs. El Chaar, 34, was until last month a portfolio manager in the treasury department of Apple Computers in Cupertino, Calif. She graduated from the University of California and received an M.B.A. from the Institut d'Études Politiques de Paris. She is the daughter of Susan D. Gordon and George B. Gordon, both of Mill Valley, Calif. Her father is the president of Western Annuity Services, money managers and financial planners in San Francisco. Her mother is a real estate agent in Greenbrae, Calif., for Pacific Union.

snippet: Review of year's notable developments finds that most cooking trends are recycled ideas that have been around for years; recipes; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: 'Some 30 million years ago, a shortage of eggs, nestlings and fruit drove the ape down from his home in the trees to see what the grasslands could provide,'' Reay Tannahill writes in ''Food in History.'' ''There he found lizards and porcupines. . . insects and grubs, and made them part of his diet.'' Things pretty much took off from there. Cavemen discovered fire -- and cooking; civilizations sprang up on the fertile land bordering great rivers. Explorers went off in search of spices; noodles were brought back from China. The Egyptians figured out how to leaven bread; the Syrians and Palestinians developed an oil-rich olive. Somewhere along the way lots of people made the joyous discovery that everything from grain to grapes could be fermented. And in 1651, François Pierre de la Varenne wrote ''Le Cuisinier Français,'' a bible of the ''new cuisine,'' which included fumets and roux and laid the foundation for the now-classic sauce béchamel.
abstract: Review of year's notable developments finds that most cooking trends are recycled ideas that have been around for years; recipes; photo (M)

snippet: "Centuries of cross-pollination, human migration, plant mutation, and a little bit of backyard luck had resulted in the pride of Idaho, the world's best baker, the Russet Burbank."
lead_paragraph: It starts with the earth. How can it not? Imagine the planet like a split peach, whose pit forms the core, whose flesh its mantle, and whose fuzzy skin its crust-no, that doesn't do justice to the crust, which is, after all, where all of life takes place. The earth's crust must be more like the rind of the orange, thicker and more durable, quite unlike the thin skin of a bruisable peach. Or is it? Funny, how you never think to wonder.
abstract: "Centuries of cross-pollination, human migration, plant mutation, and a little bit of backyard luck had resulted in the pride of Idaho, the world's best baker, the Russet Burbank."

snippet: Profile of photographer Annie Leibovitz considers qualities that distinguish her portraits; says American Music, new collection of her photos, will increase her fame; photos (L)
lead_paragraph: IN August 1991, Demi Moore appeared on the cover of Vanity Fair. As creatures from here to Uranus may recall, she was eight months pregnant and wore nothing but a diamond ring. The picture was taken by Annie Leibovitz, who, a year later, in a commemoration of the controversy, photographed the actress for the cover of Vanity Fair again. Undecided on where to shoot, Ms. Leibovitz and her crew reserved two mobile homes, four hotel rooms and five houses. Like the subjects who surrendered themselves to interminable poses in the earliest days of the camera, Ms. Moore lay for more than 13 hours as make-up artists colored virtually every square millimeter of her skin.
abstract: Profile of photographer Annie Leibovitz considers qualities that distinguish her portraits; says American Music, new collection of her photos, will increase her fame; photos (L)

snippet: Background applets are tiny utilities that can slow PC's processing speed while contributing to spontaneous lockups; they are routinely installed by drivers and adapters for software or peripherals to make applications run more quickly and smoothl...
lead_paragraph: CHRISTINA CORNISH-LAURIA was perplexed by a gradual but noticeable decline in her computer's performance. Ms. Cornish-Lauria, the executive director of a nonprofit group, regularly ran one utility that defragmented the hard drive and another that updated her antivirus software. Nonetheless, over the course of six months the PC's performance continued to deteriorate. It was taking longer to boot, and applications ran with a serene indifference to her deadlines. Finally, when Web pages with information that she needed to do her job failed to load completely, Ms. Cornish-Lauria started searching for the cause of her PC's misbehavior.
abstract: Background applets are tiny utilities that can slow PC's processing speed while contributing to spontaneous lockups; they are routinely installed by drivers and adapters for software or peripherals to make applications run more quickly and smoothly; process of uninstalling unnecessary applets described; several tools and utilities for doing job noted; drawing (M)

lead_paragraph: BY 10 a.m. on Saturdays, St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Montclair is a busy place. On one recent morning, bargain hunters filled the thrift shop, while volunteers gathered to prepare lunch for the soup kitchen. And in the sanctuary, long-stemmed lilies, snapdragons and delphiniums, along with trailing ivy and glossy andromeda foliage, sat in big buckets of water, awaiting volunteers from the church's Flower Guild.
abstract: BY 10 a.m. on Saturdays, St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Montclair is a busy place. On one recent morning, bargain hunters filled the thrift shop, while volunteers gathered to prepare lunch for the soup kitchen. And in the sanctuary, long-stemmed lilies, snapdragons and delphiniums, along with trailing ivy and glossy andromeda foliage, sat in big buckets of water, awaiting volunteers from the church's Flower Guild.     Gordon Frey and Tim Mannion arrived, spending about an hour creating two large, loose, colorful bouquets. The next morning the arrangements adorned the sanctuary at St. Luke's, a 114-year-old British-style stone church near downtown.

lead_paragraph: RETURNING to a city you love is always an iffy proposition. The vintage postcards inside your head can get a little mildewy after, say, a week of downpours in Sydney or getting pickpocketed in Prague. So there were a few jitters last June when my wife, Ruth, and I went back to Barcelona, not just because we adore the place and wanted to keep it that way but also because this time we were meeting up with my in-laws.

lead_paragraph: ASTORIA, across the East River from Manhattan on the northwest tip of Queens, always has been a neighborhood of affordable beginnings. Waves of Germans, Czechs, Irish, Italians and Greeks followed, working-class folk who bought into the American dream and local real estate.

snippet: New York Yankees  Yankee Stadium 161st St. (at River Ave.), Bronx (718) 293-6000 www.yankees.com. One of the most storied venues in sports history, Yankee Stadium may be a little worn around the edges, but there's no denying its aura. The origina...
lead_paragraph: New York Yankees — Yankee Stadium 161st St. (at River Ave.), Bronx (718) 293-6000 www.yankees.com. One of the most storied venues in sports history, Yankee Stadium may be a little worn around the edges, but there's no denying its aura. The original stadium opened in 1923, as 74,200 fans packed the massive three-tiered facility and watched Babe Ruth christen his new home with a towering shot as the Yankees beat their hated rivals, the Boston Red Sox. Because Ruth was such a tremendous draw, Yankee Stadium almost immediately acquired its moniker, "The House that Ruth Built." The park was remodeled and scaled down slightly in the mid-70's, but historic touches remain, including Monument Park and the decorative white colonnade above the outfield. Some of baseball's most legendary names have played at the Stadium, including Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio, Yogi Berra and Mickey Mantle, to name but a few. It was here that Gehrig delivered his famous farewell address ("Today I consider myself the luckiest man on the face of the earth"), and here that three perfect games have been hurled (by Don Larsen, David Wells and David Cone). The current team, World Champions in 1996, 1998, 1999 and 2000, is a perennial contender to do it again-just like the "Murderer's Row" squads of the 1920's and 1930's, and the unstoppable Yankees juggernaut of the early 1960's. Buy tickets in advance, and take public transporation to the stadium (traffic is a nightmare). Don't miss the raucous chants from Bleacher Creatures-as if you could. Hardcore fans can take stadium tours; call (718) 579-4531 or check the Web site for details. Tickets: $8-$65; available through Ticketmaster, at www.yankees.com, at the stadium or at Yankees Clubhouse stores. Subway: 4, B, D to 161st St.-Yankee Stadium.

lead_paragraph: THE would-be governance revolution of a decade ago had its casualties. Men who rose to the very top of the very top companies in the United States were suddenly -- and very publicly -- jobless. For most of them, however, being toppled from their thrones did not mean staying out of the management chair for long.

lead_paragraph: IF ignorance is bliss, Kevin O'Connor is one happy man. Last year, he was a new homeowner who couldn't figure out how to strip his wallpaper. Next month he joins Norm Abram, Tom Silva and the rest of the ''This Old House'' team to become their improbable new host.
abstract: IF ignorance is bliss, Kevin O'Connor is one happy man. Last year, he was a new homeowner who couldn't figure out how to strip his wallpaper. Next month he joins Norm Abram, Tom Silva and the rest of the ''This Old House'' team to become their improbable new host.    Such is the curious fortune of Mr. O'Connor, 35, a freckle-faced banker from Boston whose biggest claim to fame used to be approving loans to sports teams like the Red Sox. That was before he was tapped to replace Steve Thomas, host of ''This Old House'' for 14 years.

The city of Long Beach, Calif., plans to announce on Friday that it will make free wireless Internet access available in its downtown area as part of an effort to attract visitors and companies to the business district.    Long Beach is one of a growing number of cities and community groups that are considering free wireless Internet access. A number of cities are exploring the idea of installing such networks in downtown areas or throughout entire communities. [Page C7.]

lead_paragraph: GENERALLY, it's not a good sign when a restaurant starts fiddling and fussing with its format, and few restaurants have done more fiddling and fussing in recent years than the Tonic, now reborn as Amuse. Every few months, it seemed, a press release would announce a new chef, a new concept and a new dawn. The place seemed to be caught in a rolling identity crisis. Was it a glorified saloon? A hip lounge? A music club? A fine-dining destination? All of the above, and so much more, according to its publicists.

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Newburyport, Mass; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: BLOCKS of refined red brick Federalist and Georgian mercantile buildings and dazzling centuries-old white mansions announce that Newburyport, now the smallest coastal city in Massachusetts, with just 17,000 residents, was once a much more prominent place. And so it was: a rival port to Boston, 40 miles to the south, in the 1700's and a cosmopolitan center of shipbuilding, commerce, craftsmanship and letters. Now, relieved of the burden of so much importance, it can afford to be easygoing and charming, reverent of its history while reveling in its salty side with public beaches, whale watching trips, lobster dinners and lots of fine bakeries. SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

Outside the gates of what was once Loring Air Force Base, thousands of fans were lined up in their vehicles, ready to enter It, a weekend-long music festival featuring Phish, the popular improvisational rock band. A big part of the festival plan was the Bunny, Phish's name for the 100,000-watt FM radio station that the band had leased for the weekend. lead_paragraph: Q. What is the difference between the MPEG-1, MPEG-2 and MPEG-4 video formats?
abstract: Q. What is the difference between the MPEG-1, MPEG-2 and MPEG-4 video formats?    A. MPEG-1, MPEG-2 and MPEG-4 are compression standards used for digital video. All of the formats were developed by the Motion Picture Experts Group, part of the International Organization for Standardization, which develops technical standards.      The MPEG-1 standard creates a digital video file with a typical resolution of 352 by 240 pixels at a rate of 30 frames per second. The picture quality of video compressed with the MPEG-1 standard usually was similar to that found on a VHS tape, and the format was often used for clips incorporated into CD-ROM's.

lead_paragraph: As I was driving south a few months ago from Jackson toward Cora beneath the Wind River Range in western Wyoming, I noticed a herd of antelope grazing in a pasture, separated by a barbed-wire fence from the blacktop that stretched in a diminishing V toward the distant mountains like an image on an eye chart. Since I had never been to Wyoming before and had no idea how untamed it still was, I assumed I had come upon a zoo or the private herd of an eccentric rancher. It didn't occur to me that in Wyoming the buffalo still roam, the deer and the antelope play and the skies are not cloudy all day.

snippet: With the resurgence of 1950's styles in strikingly visual movies like "Far From Heaven" and in clothing collections by designers like Marc Jacobs, it follows that the beauty industry would catch the midcentury wave. Mass-market brands like Calgon ...
lead_paragraph: For women who are wearyof last fall's milelong mufflers in heavy, hand-knit yarns, designers are providing warmth for the second leg of winter in less bulky crochet. The crocheted mufflers, which evoke the granny-made afghan blankets and potholders of yore, come in a variety of yarn weights and patterns, and serve as a transition into spring, when crocheted capes and tops will take their place. At Saks Fifth Avenue, delicate scarves by Sophie Digard have floral, circle (left) and petal-shape patterns in rich pastel wool ($175). A dark plum scarf by Justine Brooke (center) does away with fringe and tassels and sports a slit in one end through which the other end can be fed ($150 at Bergdorf Goodman). Henri Bendel offers protection in the form of an extralong neck warmer, which appears to have been inspired by crocheted potholders (far left, $148). At Barneys New York , there are leaf-pattern shawls by Yadi Knits in metallic pastel cottons ($395). And on the other end of the disposable-income spectrum, American Eagle Outfitters has put its fringed muffler of crocheted squares on sale. It rings in at just over $7 at www.ae.com . Given these choices, what would Granny do?
abstract: With the resurgence of 1950's styles in strikingly visual movies like "Far From Heaven" and in clothing collections by designers like Marc Jacobs, it follows that the beauty industry would catch the midcentury wave. Mass-market brands like Calgon bath products and Toni Perms, which became household names in the early 50's, have recently come out with repackaged versions of the original products. Next month, Dippity-do, the iconic bright pink or blue hair gel, will rerelease its original formula, along with the new Dippity-do Techno, a tweaked version for teenagers ($2.99 at CVS). In the higher-end cosmetic arena, Delux Beauty named its Tintsticks, sheer lip colors for spring, after 50's waitresses — Flossie, Darling, Dot and Betty. And Stila's spring makeup line is based on the corals and reds of the classic 50's palette. "The 50's look is very appealing right now because it's so cinematic," said Jeanine Lobell, creator of Stila. "The look is all about black eyeliner, neutral eyeshadows, peachy coral cheeks and bright coral to red lips. It's a perfect complement to modern fashion because it has a slightly ironic, tongue-in-cheek quality.".

On Monday, Ms. Stewart's company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, introduced a new populist recipe magazine called Everyday Food.    The size of a TV Guide, the magazine is designed to compete at grocery checkout counters with the busy cheese-and-chicken magazines published by companies like Pillsbury. What's unusual about Everyday Food is that, unlike almost every product, show and publication previously put forth by the company, Ms. Stewart's signature blond hair and practiced smile are missing from all but a few small ads.

snippet: "A private American foundation was paying Elizabeth Dinakar to train local doctors in the principles of microbiology."
lead_paragraph: On the first morning of the training in Bombay, just minutes before she collapsed, Elizabeth Dinakar stood in front of two hundred people in the conference hall, pointed up at the cholera bacteria magnified on the wall in front of her, and said "This is your enemy." The room was long and stuffy, with peeling walls and rattling air conditioners. People coughed and shuffled papers. The bacteria were the size of cars. Elizabeth Dinakar was tall and thin with thick black eyebrows. Her hair was pulled away from her face and held in a bun at the back of her head. She wore a silk shirt and khaki skirt, flat-soled shoes, and no makeup.

snippet: Eve Ashcraft, color specialist, shares some of her secrets on how to select paint colors; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: NOW, bolder colors are back. But faced with the thousands of paint colors available, 80 percent of us default to some version of white. To bail us out, the color specialist Eve Ashcraft has agreed to share some of her secrets on how to pick those colors, and how to apply them. Trained as a fine artist, Ms. Ashcraft has selected wall paints for Steve Martin and mixed luminous glazes for Rick Moranis. She also designed Martha Stewart's first paint line, based on the eggs of Ms. Stewart's Araucana chickens.

lead_paragraph: ZOLA'S ascendancy to the height of culinary fashion in this buttoned-up city was assured one night in early February when Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, descended the restaurant's stairs just as Michael Jordan and Patrick Ewing arrived after a Washington Wizards basketball game in the nearby MCI Center. In this town where politicians are as recognizable as Hollywood stars and celebrity athletes, the three men greeted one another warmly before going their separate ways.

snippet: Article on chef Daniel Boulud, who conveniently lives in apartment above his restaurant Daniel; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Daniel Boulud says his classic-six apartment on 65th Street and Park Avenue, above his restaurant Daniel, lacks one essential ingredient: a good kitchen. His is so small and boxy that he rarely uses it for anything other than making coffee. ''My dream was to extend the kitchen onto the terrace and build a glass roof over it,'' he says. ''But the building wouldn't let me.'' Boulud, who also owns DB Bistro Moderne and Café Boulud, has lived in his three-bedroom home for the last five years. And while he appreciates his two-story commute to work, which keeps him close to his wife and 13-year-old daughter, it's in his nature to tinker. His list of projects includes painting the white walls a warmer color, converting the guest bedroom into an office to store his cookbooks and Cognacs and replacing the old zebra-print couch in the den. ''That couch, how do you say it? It's trashed.''
abstract: Article on chef Daniel Boulud, who conveniently lives in apartment above his restaurant Daniel; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: In his last letter home from the war zone, Cpl. Michael E. Curtin said he felt sorry for some of the soldiers in his platoon. They did not receive as many letters and care packages as he did, so he gave his family several names and asked that they write to them. It was, his family said, a telling gesture by a man known for his thoughtfulness.

snippet: Anne Raver Cuttings column on perennial seeds available through catalogs and nurseries; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: MY cutting garden is all over the place, from the tulips that bloom by the smokehouse door, to the overgrown lilacs and mock oranges by the kitchen window, to the butterfly bushes and fennel in the vegetable garden. But this year, I'm expanding my collection of perennials to include many I've been reading about in books by Piet Oudolf, a Dutch nurseryman with an uncanny eye for plant combinations. ''Designing With Plants'' (Timber Press, 1999), written with Noel Kingsbury and illustrated with Mr. Oudolf's spectacular photographs, suggests ways that unusual plants, from grasses to angelicas and thistle-like sea hollies, can be used as cut flowers.
abstract: Anne Raver Cuttings column on perennial seeds available through catalogs and nurseries; drawing (M)

lead_paragraph: Q. I have two computers that I would like to use with just one monitor, keyboard and mouse to save space. How can I set this up?
abstract: Q. I have two computers that I would like to use with just one monitor, keyboard and mouse to save space. How can I set this up?    A. Having two computers hooked up to one monitor can save a lot of desk space. You can even connect computers with different operating systems to the same monitor and easily switch back and forth. With the right kind of hardware, you can also use the same keyboard and mouse for the two computers.

snippet: "When it comes to Iris the rules he has made for himself are simple: look but don't touch, long for but don't have, think but don't say."
lead_paragraph: Daniel and Hampton were paired by chance and against their wishes. They were not friends - Hampton did not particularly like Daniel, and Daniel had every reason to avoid being alone with Hampton. But Daniel's girlfriend or partner or whatever he was supposed to call her, Kate, Kate went home to relieve the baby-sitter who was minding her daughter, and Hampton's wife, there was no ambiguity there, his wife, Iris, with whom Daniel was fiercely in love, had gone home to look after their son. Daniel and Hampton stayed behind to search for a blind girl, a heartsick and self-destructive blind girl who had run away from today's cocktail party, either to get lost or to be found, no one was sure.
abstract: "When it comes to Iris the rules he has made for himself are simple: look but don't touch, long for but don't have, think but don't say."

snippet: Wayne Curtis travel article on weekend road trip from Brattleboro, Vt, into New Hampshire; photos; map (M)
lead_paragraph: An essential element -- perhaps the essential element -- in a successful road trip is that it deliver you from the congested to the empty, from a cluttered landscape to an open one. For residents along the East Coast, that usually means striking westward, a tactic that's worked since at least the days of Henry David Thoreau, who said, ''Eastward I go only by force; but westward I go free.''

snippet: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column recalls New York City in late 1980's and early 1990's as place of extreme violence and fear; says single most important factor in its renaissance over past decade was remarkable drop in crime, and of one of big reasons for...
lead_paragraph: Early one morning in January 1990 the actress Viveca Lindfors was attacked by a stranger in Greenwich Village and slashed in the face. ''It happened so unbearably fast,'' she said at the time. ''One minute we were coming out of the building, talking about Gorbachev and Lithuania, and suddenly a guy was right in front of me, holding my face. And the next second I was lying on the street. I heard screams, 'Get him!' And I felt the blood.''
abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column recalls New York City in late 1980's and early 1990's as place of extreme violence and fear; says single most important factor in its renaissance over past decade was remarkable drop in crime, and of one of big reasons for crime drop was huge expansion of police force; says Mayor Michael Bloomberg, faced with budget deficit, is talking about laying off police for first time in almost three decades; says city may pay for this move in blood (M)

snippet: Article on Berchman Sydney Augustine, artist known as Berch, who paints custom images and seasonal greetings on shop windows and walls in Astoria, Queens; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: BERCHMAN SYDNEY AUGUSTINE paints pizza pies on pizza parlors. He paints blocks of ham and cheese on deli windows. He painted the head of a cow on a butcher shop, ''and I'm a vegetarian -- crazy, right?'' Mr. Augustine, or Berch, as he signs his work, earns his keep painting custom images and seasonal greetings on shop windows and walls along Broadway, Ditmars Boulevard and other streets in Astoria, Queens. Where ordinary people see a jumble of decidedly unglamorous shops, Mr. Augustine sees a giant canvas, and a living.

snippet: Daisy Garnett profiles industrial designer Tord Boontje; photos (part 2 of 2-part section) (L)
lead_paragraph: Tord Boontje is a mild-mannered, unassuming industrial designer of profound integrity who has lately become a star. The 34-year-old Dutchman, who lives in London, doesn't look like a star; he looks more like, say, an art teacher. You have to sit very close to hear him talk, which he does generously, but with quiet self-effacement. Still, these days, a star he is, and for the purest reason: people have fallen for his work in a big way.

lead_paragraph: LIKE any number of disenchanted, deskbound New Yorkers, Dan Bollinger dreamed of quitting his job and starting his own business. Mr. Bollinger, 33, an accountant at an interior design firm, had an idea -- turning his hobby of making all-natural soaps into a full-time enterprise -- but he lacked money to get the business off the ground and out of his kitchen. He did, however, have lots of soap -- bars and bars of the stuff, curing in the nooks and crannies of his Brooklyn brownstone.

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Beverly Hills, Calif; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: IF the thought of a visit to the Los Angeles area conjures up images of overpacked theme parks, hackneyed studio tours and traffic, leave the city for Beverly Hills. Slip on your sunglasses -- in this land of make-believe, rose-tinted lenses are most popular -- and wiggle into your low-riders. Put on your walking shoes, too. Surprisingly, much of what's fun in Beverly Hills can be done on foot. You may notice that summer in Beverly Hills does not involve heat, humidity or mosquitoes. It is dry; daytime temperatures are usually in the mid-70's. Stroll along the tree-lined streets, stargazing and enjoying the views of the Hollywood hills. Splurge at a shop or a spa. Try an expensive restaurant, but don't have your mouth full when Halle Berry slides into the banquette nearby. ANN COLIN HERBST
abstract: Article on 36-hour visit to Beverly Hills, Calif; photos; maps (M)

snippet: A O Scott article contends every generation has fought for best possible education for its children, always devolving into politically contentious battles; says goal is perfection, which by its nature is guarantee of failure; says problem is combi...
lead_paragraph: On weekday mornings, after a hurried breakfast of frozen waffles and scrambled eggs and a two-block dash through the neighborhood crush of strollers and briefcases, my 6-year-old son slips his backpack over his shoulders, grants me a desultory hug and passes through the double doors of the school bus into the care of the New York City public school system. He is the apple of my eye, my hostage to fortune, every sentimental paternal cliché you can think of and also, like every other child on the bus, a pawn in an endless political chess game. Along with the peanut butter and jelly sandwich and last night's homework, that blue nylon school bag is weighted down with a century's worth of ideological baggage. And my own parochial parental anxieties -- Is he happy? Is he learning? Is he making friends? -- are, whether I like it or not, shrill notes in a cacophony of political contention, along with the thundering of officeholders, the rumbling of bureaucrats and the horn bleats of think-tank intellectuals.
abstract: A O Scott article contends every generation has fought for best possible education for its children, always devolving into politically contentious battles; says goal is perfection, which by its nature is guarantee of failure; says problem is combination of high expectations and conflicting priorities; photo (M)

snippet: Article on subculture of scientists, philosophers, futurists and other high-minded anorectics who have taken up and advocate calorie restriction, or CR, diet, in effort to substantially extend life span; Calorie Restriction Society has about 900 u...
lead_paragraph: IN his quest to reach the age of 143, Michael A. Sherman is making his peace with doughnuts. Renouncing potato skins and chocolate-chip pancakes was no problem, but he just hasn't found a substitute for a glazed, oven-warm bear claw oozing with apple filling. ''I love them, but the larger specimens of that species can approach 1,000 calories,'' he said a few weeks before Thanksgiving, a holiday he can't get overly excited about. ''That's almost as much as I allow myself in a whole day.''

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Cape May, NJ; photos; maps; chart (M)
lead_paragraph: AS soon as summer heralds its presence, tourists descend upon this Victorian resort at New Jersey's southern tip. The town, with a permanent population of 4,200, plays host to a half-million visitors annually -- most of them during the summer. An outdoorsy mentality has thrived on this 3.5-square-mile island (a canal makes it an island) for quite some time -- ever since the Kechemeche Indians hunted and fished here. In 1620, Cornelius Jacobsen Mey, a Dutch explorer, navigated the coastline and gave his name to the area, though the spelling was later changed to May. Breeze-seeking Philadelphians eventually made Cape May one of the nation's first seaside resorts. Today, entrance to Cape May's two miles of public beaches requires adults to pay as they go ($4 per day, $8 for three days), in the form of beach tags, which are sold around town. While the fee may be a nuisance, it helps to ensure immaculate beaches. And although Victoriana is a major attraction in Cape May, you can also stumble upon rolling farmland, thick woods and semideserted dunes, just as past explorers did generations ago. CHRISTINE EGAN
abstract: Article on 36-hour visit to Cape May, NJ; photos; maps; chart (M)

lead_paragraph: MY cutting garden is all over the place, from the tulips that bloom by the smokehouse door, to the overgrown lilacs and mock oranges by the kitchen window, to the butterfly bushes and fennel in the vegetable garden.
abstract: MY cutting garden is all over the place, from the tulips that bloom by the smokehouse door, to the overgrown lilacs and mock oranges by the kitchen window, to the butterfly bushes and fennel in the vegetable garden.      But this year, I'm expanding my collection of perennials to include many I've been reading about in books by Piet Oudolf, a Dutch nurseryman with an uncanny eye for plant combinations. ''Designing With Plants'' (Timber Press, 1999), written with Noel Kingsbury and illustrated with Mr. Oudolf's spectacular photographs, suggests ways that unusual plants, from grasses to angelicas and thistle-like sea hollies, can be used as cut flowers.

headline.main: Satisfying a Yen for More and More Perennials

lead_paragraph: LESLIE CAGAN is willing to count many things. She will count the billions the United States will spend if it goes to war in Iraq. She will count the dead. She will count the oil companies that line up for the spoils. She will count the nations that turn their backs on this country in anger. And she will, on Feb. 15, count the demonstrators who are to gather in Manhattan and three dozen cities around the globe to rally to stop the war. She will count all this. She is counting now.

snippet: The C.I.A. setting, the utterly predictable plot twists, the chase scenes and the climactic bout of gunplay may suggest a thriller, but really this slick and pointless exercise belongs to a more specialized genre: the Al Pacino crazy mentor pictur...
lead_paragraph: ''The Recruit,'' which opens nationwide today, takes place within the shadowy world of the Central Intelligence Agency, where, we are repeatedly told, nothing is what it seems. This is true of the movie as well: it seems like a spy thriller, but it really isn't. Sure, there are car and foot chases, some gunplay, a lot of breathless exposition and the frenetic uploading and downloading of files that is a staple of the modern high-tech Hollywood suspense film.
abstract: The C.I.A. setting, the utterly predictable plot twists, the chase scenes and the climactic bout of gunplay may suggest a thriller, but really this slick and pointless exercise belongs to a more specialized genre: the Al Pacino crazy mentor picture. This time, Mr. Pacino is Walter Burke, whose job is to recruit and train intelligence operatives. "I have a scary eye for talent," he says. What Mr. Pacino displays is his peculiar, and often amusing, gift for ranting, spluttering and braying, and his wildly unpredictable, borderline-incoherent performance is the only interesting thing in the movie. Colin Farrell, as Burke's troubled protégé, James Clayton, an M.I.T. graduate student who seems to have misplaced his shaving kit in all the excitement, works very hard without producing anything like the casual, nutty intensity Mr. Pacino can summon so effortlessly. Bridget Moynahan is James's fellow trainee and love interest, who may or may not be a mole. — A. O. Scott

lead_paragraph: FROM their conception, Palm organizers have been designed according to what its employees only half-jokingly call the Zen of Palm: a belief in simplicity, minimizing the steps required for each task and avoiding superfluous features. snippet: No movie title could be any less appropriate than "Basic." Someone decided to make a procedural thriller by putting  "Rashomon" in a Cuisinart along with "A Few Good Men" and "A Soldier's Story," and hit the...
lead_paragraph: I'm not sure a movie title could be any less appropriate than ''Basic''; it makes less sense than any explanation the cast could possibly offer for appearing in this ridiculous procedural thriller. For the actors, at least, there is what Balzac called the purest of motives: money. But because no one will be paid to see this film -- or in this case, paid enough to see it -- questions over its existence will continue to plague us.
abstract: No movie title could be any less appropriate than "Basic." Someone decided to make a procedural thriller by putting  "Rashomon" in a Cuisinart along with "A Few Good Men" and "A Soldier's Story," and hit the button for pulverize while forgetting to replace the top. The outcome is a spewing mess. In Panama, six Army Rangers go out on a training exercise, led  by their volatile, violently demanding — and, of course, violently detested — troop leader, Sergeant West (Samuel L. Jackson). When only two of the men return alive, an investigation begins. Hardy (John Travolta), a bad-apple D.E.A. agent and former Ranger, is brought in to find out what went wrong. "Basic" is so desperate to get to its nonsensical ending that it sinks to having a dying man write a clue in his own blood. Probably the reason most people will be interested in "Basic" is for a re-teaming of Mr. Travolta and Mr. Jackson for the first time since "Pulp Fiction." They have only a moment together, and this picture could have the effect of negating the heat "Pulp Fiction" put under them. — Elvis Mitchell

I never questioned his seating choices, but I wondered about his fish. Pickled herring was the perfect accompaniment to any meal, with large turkeys, asparagus, even barbecue. To my grandfather, herring was a comfort food as basic as apple pie.

snippet: Jonathan Reynolds article on Jean-Georges Vongerichten, who is about to open new restaurant called 66 in TriBeCa featuring Chinese haute cuisine; recipes; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Jean-Georges Vongerichten has the most confident walk in New York. Bouncy like a boxer's yet turned out like a dancer's (he chops and slices standing in second position), its bantam-cock ebullience signals both purpose and delight. This exuberance isn't just a matter of his own critical and entrepreneurial success but the personification of the epigram ''If you love your work, you'll never have a job.'' He's about to open a new restaurant (ye gods, another?) in TriBeCa called 66, which will bring his total to five in New York alone (six counting the sandwich drop-by Lipstick Café). If you can map the inner contentment of a man by his outward appearance and gesture, J.G.V. is an ecstatic. ''I work in my office from 9 to 12, then go to therapy,'' he says, adding, with perfect timing and a glint of hazel eye, '' . . . cooking!''

snippet: Julia Reed
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, when Anne Kearney, the chef at Peristyle in New Orleans, put a nightly charcuterie plate on the menu, I was thrilled. Since Peristyle, which she owns with her husband, Tom Sand, is around the corner from my house, I was already pretty happy -- when I'm in town, nothing gives me more pleasure than to belly up to its magnificent copper bar for a glass of Bandol rosé and a pissaladière. The staff never fails to cheer me up when I am down, the fax machine does duty when mine is broken and, most important, the menu offers wonderful takes on the food I love most: poached oysters with cream, bacon, leeks and fennel; lump-crab salad with fresh horseradish and beets; gougères, hot at the table; a classic lemon tart for dessert. And now, on the charcuterie plate, fabulous terrines.

lead_paragraph: ELAINE MARSHALL was in the L. L. Bean store in Freeport, Me., recently, strolling around the luggage department, checking out the camping gear and surveying the women's wear. snippet: "Shed taken on a big commission, a huge Christ for the cathedral, it should have been well on the way by now . . ."
lead_paragraph: CHRISTMAS WAS OVER. Feeling a shame-faced pleasure in the restoration of normality, Kate stripped the tree of lights and decorations, cut off the main branches and dragged the trunk down to the compost heap at the bottom of the garden. There she stood looking back at the house, empty again now-her mother and sister had left the morning after Boxing Day-seeing the lighted windows and reflected firelight almost as if she were a stranger, shut out. A few specks of cold rain found her eyelids and mouth. All around her the forest waited, humped in silence. Shivering, she ran back up the lawn.
abstract: "Shed taken on a big commission, a huge Christ for the cathedral, it should have been well on the way by now . . ."

lead_paragraph: JUSTIN MOORE, a 27-year-old transplant from Florida who came to New York nearly three years ago, talks about his goals as if he has already achieved them. All he has ever wanted to be is a rock star, and he may have what it takes. Slinky and lean, with silky dark hair and a mysterious scar on his left cheek, he radiates charm and a certain bad-boy mystique. There is something sweet about him, too.

snippet: William Grimes reviews Lamu, restaurant in Manhattan's Flatiron district; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: BY rights, Lamu should suffer from a crippling inferiority complex. It sits just a few doors down from Craft, and around the corner from hot spots like Gramercy Tavern and Patria. The limousines that clog the area after dark serve as a painful reminder that big money and celebrity diners hover nearby, physically close but inhabiting a different universe. In the battle to win the attention of New York diners, Lamu seems like the little guy who doesn't stand a chance.

He had been raised on a rich diet of visually explosive games for sophisticated consoles by Sega and Nintendo. He had also found himself playing even more interactive games that required joysticks, mice and keyboards plugged into hulking desktop computers.
abstract: NOT so long ago Pedro A. Arellano, 20, wouldn't have thought much about turning to his cellphone to indulge his penchant for video games. He had been raised on a rich diet of visually explosive games for sophisticated consoles by Sega and Nintendo. He had also found himself playing even more interactive games that required joysticks, mice and keyboards plugged into hulking desktop computers.     But these days Mr. Arellano, a computer science and finance major at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, says he is increasingly enticed by a different kind of video game: the $4 or $5 variety he can play on his cellphone screen.

Palm trees laid a blanket of shade over her second-floor balcony, cooling the hundreds of perfectly crafted burekas and bulemas, flaky pastries filled with feta cheese, spinach and potatoes that she had set out in foil pans. As she has done for the last 36 years, she would send some to friends, saving the rest for her family.

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Santa Catalina Island, Calif; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: SOME people go to Santa Catalina Island, 22 miles off the coast of Southern California, to see the buffalo, imported for the filming of an obscure 1925 movie, ''The Vanishing American,'' and long ago gone wild. But the abundant native wildlife is even more of a draw. Dolphins may swim up to meet your boat and sea lions sun themselves on the rocky coast. On the island itself, just an hour's ferry ride from Long Beach, you will find a decidedly Mediterranean flavor. The view from the boat as you approach Catalina is of a busy, energetic harbor lined with small vessels. The arid rugged interior is peppered with fragrant trees and flowers. The 3,700 year-round residents in the charming port town of Avalon, the only sizable settlement on the 76-square-mile island, are proud of its shops, beaches and year-round temperate climate. Get to the ferry terminal early and jockey for a spot on the boat or you might be left behind.
abstract: Article on 36-hour visit to Santa Catalina Island, Calif; photos; maps (M)

snippet: Mark Stevens article on Beijing, China, as it mixes its past with modern, capitalistic accouterments; photos (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (L)
lead_paragraph: 'You have to understand. Beijing was wonderful during SARS,'' said Jeremy Wingfield, the manager of the CourtYard Gallery. ''Romantic, beautiful. The sky was clear, for once. Everything shut down. There was no smog or dust or traffic jams. No tourists. No cars.'' He looked at me closely, to make sure I was the sort of American who understood that, of course, he also knew that SARS was a terrible plague that killed people. But it was important nonetheless to acknowledge the marvel of the moment when Beijing stopped. ''One day they announced SARS was over,'' he said, almost wistfully. ''And it was as if nothing had ever happened.''

In the opening song of Aarktica's new album, ''Pure Tone Audiometry'' (Silber), Jon DeRosa wonders, ''Am I out to sea, farther than I need to be?/To find my way home, I don't know.'' Aarktica's songs are extended reveries, built on loops of guitars and drums and occasional voices. The musical elements hover and circle, float by or bristle with distortion as the songs drift through serenity and trouble. Sunday night, with Echo at 7, the Mobius Band at 8, Aarktica at 9 and Healamonster and Tarier at 10; admission is $8 (Jon Pareles).

lead_paragraph: EVERYONE needs a neighborhood restaurant for those days when cooking dinner seems impossible. Bostonians are no different. Ambitious local restaurateurs have turned that to their advantage, eschewing Newbury Street's soaring rents to populate residential neighborhoods where there is steady demand. I'm not talking about pizzerias and Chinese takeout; these are serious, often white-tablecloth establishments that are winning national attention. An additional benefit is that they are blessedly free of over-the-top flourishes.

abstract: SURROUNDED by forest, glacial peaks and the cobalt waters of the Strait of Georgia, this comfortable Vancouver Island town of 12,000 is a popular center for outdoor recreation on the far western fringe of Canada. Visitors come to fish, hike, sail and ski, or simply to enjoy the spectacular scenery. No one comes expecting architectural treasure.    But on a 200-foot seaside bluff just outside Comox, a midcentury Modernist house bears witness to the prodigious talent of its designer -- a once prominent figure in North American architecture who is largely unknown in the United States -- and to the tenacity of an owner who recently saved it.

snippet: Dragons, much more than other mythical creatures, have long and well-documented history from images on Babylon's Ishtar Gate to Inuit native bone carvings; persistence of myth in historical records coupled with references of remarkable similarity ...
lead_paragraph: A huge scaly serpent, usually with the wings of a bat or bird. Four or two or no legs. Breathes fire or poisonous fumes. May talk, but won't take guff from mere mortals. Sometimes has a vulnerable underbelly (good luck, Siegfried!) and sometimes is solid armor plate. May guard a treasure. May diet on virgins, or anything that crosses its path, halitosis-barbecued.
abstract: Dragons, much more than other mythical creatures, have long and well-documented history from images on Babylon's Ishtar Gate to Inuit native bone carvings; persistence of myth in historical records coupled with references of remarkable similarity found throughout many separate and sometimes isolated cultures cause researchers to question where myth came from and if it ever took on true physical form; early enlightenment thinkers may have seen fossils and bones of dinosaurs that made them believe that dragons existed; medieval Christian thinkers had Biblical references and story of Noah to justify existence and extinction of dragons; Dr David E Jones, author of An Instinct for Dragons and anthropology professor at University of Central Florida in Orlando, believes dragons are image of early man's nightmares as he struggled against predators; numerous dragon theories are posed and historical outline given; drawings; photos; map (L)

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Atlanta, Ga; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: FOR a city so rich in history -- from its burning by General Sherman to the birth of Martin Luther King Jr. -- and widely considered the cultural capital of the Southeast, Atlanta can feel like a gawky teenager, a self-conscious striver without a settled sense of itself. With a downtown that shuts down by night, Atlantans drive home to their signature neighborhoods, pockets in and around the city that define their inhabitants. Perhaps the best known of these is Buckhead, a semi-urban sprawl of strip malls, mansions (both old and new), world-class shopping and dining and a night-life scene with something for every kind of frat boy. But skip that scene to explore the older, ever-regenerating neighborhoods of this city to discover Atlanta's lesser-known charms.

snippet: Susan Jacoby travel article on lovingly restored 19th-century homes and mansions in Marshall, Mich, whose residents are preparing for their 40th annual historic home tour; more than 850 structures are in town's National Historic Landmark District;...
lead_paragraph: IN 1847, the settlers of Marshall, a southern Michigan town strategically set on the stagecoach route between Detroit and Chicago, received unwelcome news. Expected by its founders to become the state capital, Marshall lost out through political chicanery (as local lore has it) to its upstart neighbor, Lansing. Today the old affront looks more like a blessing. On the one hand, Marshall, 171 miles east of Chicago and 117 miles west of Detroit on the railroad line that soon replaced stagecoaches, lost its chance to become the center of state government. On the other, the absence of development meant that hundreds of 19th-century houses were preserved and passed down for generations, making Marshall (population 7,459) a magnet for those who crave a weekend ''where the fast lane ends'' (as the chamber of commerce boasts on its Web site).
abstract: Susan Jacoby travel article on lovingly restored 19th-century homes and mansions in Marshall, Mich, whose residents are preparing for their 40th annual historic home tour; more than 850 structures are in town's National Historic Landmark District; photos; map (L)

snippet: What's Doing In column on upcoming events, sightseeing, lodging and restaurants in San Francisco, Calif; photos; map; chart (M)
lead_paragraph: A sound not heard in San Francisco for two years reverberated along the waterfront 12 days ago. The clock on the historic Ferry Building, frozen during a renovation completed in March, was set in motion and once again chimes on the hour and half-hour. The clock had been stopped only three times before, by earthquakes, and its chiming signals the Ferry Building's rebirth. Though its soaring interior still feels slightly empty after being closed for three years, the Ferry Building is slowly filling with permanent vendors who will turn it by summer's end into a showplace of Bay Area food.
abstract: What's Doing In column on upcoming events, sightseeing, lodging and restaurants in San Francisco, Calif; photos; map; chart (M)

lead_paragraph: A LAPTOP may make a powerful portable office, but as a pure note-taking device, it is not universally considered an improvement over handwriting. In meetings, the laptop's screen becomes a wall that psychologically isolates you from the group. For people who don't touch-type, handwriting is faster, too. And then there's the clicking of the keys -- a distinct liability when it comes to note-taking in, say, church.

snippet: A scorching anecdotal history of gang warfare in the slums of Rio de Janeiro, "City of God" is narrated by Rocket (Alexandre Rodrigues), a young photographer who chronicles the deterioration of the housing project in which he grew up fro...
lead_paragraph: In ''City of God,'' Fernando Meirelles's scorching anecdotal history of violence in the slums of Rio de Janeiro, a fretful boy with the cute nickname Steak & Fries (Darlan Cunha), begs for a gun that would certify his membership in one of two rival gangs. ''I smoke, I snort, I've killed and robbed,'' he pleads none too convincingly. ''I'm a man.''
abstract: A scorching anecdotal history of gang warfare in the slums of Rio de Janeiro, "City of God" is narrated by Rocket (Alexandre Rodrigues), a young photographer who chronicles the deterioration of the housing project in which he grew up from a shantytown into a war zone. The movie, which begins in the 1960's and ends in the early 80's, parallels Rocket's story with the rise of his childhood playmate Li'l Ze (Leandro Firmino da Hora) from a petty thief into a ruthless, drug dealer and neighborhood kingpin commanding a small army of gun-toting children. The history is told in a loose, tall-tale style that suggests a quasi-cinema-verite version of Martin Scorsese's "GoodFellas." — Stephen Holden

snippet: About 400 private gardens will be open to public during Garden Conservancy's Open Days program this year; guide to gardens; photos; chart (L)
lead_paragraph: THE hill behind Peggy and Walter Jones's house in Englewood, N.J., should be a cloud of pink and white rhododendrons by May 18, when they open their garden to the public as one of 400 private gardens in the Garden Conservancy's Open Days program this year. Subtle pleasures are to be had there, like the swamp azalea, with its delicate pink blossom, that seeded itself in the damp swale at the bottom of a wooded slope. In this moist, humusy soil, enriched by years of leaf mulch, the primroses are so happy they are self-seeding among the ferns and moving right into the lawn.

snippet: Journeys article on 36-hour visit to Kauai, Hawaii; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: KAUAI is a hot spot, and its beautiful North Shore, where majestic mountains meet the surging sea, is hottest. Twenty years ago, when Maui was the place, Kauaians grinned and thought, ''Good, we got ours and we're going to keep it that way.'' Now, residents make their livings catering to tourists and pampering the movie stars and magnates who are collecting North Shore trophy homes. But with 60,000 people, this is still the least populated of the major Hawaiian islands, and its spacious white beaches ring a lush, untrammeled interior. Kauai roads may not be marked, and numbers are rarely posted, so it helps to memorize the two most important directional words -- mauka, meaning toward the mountains, and makai, for toward the ocean. When you ask directions, be ready for an answer like this: ''Go a mile to the big mango tree, take a left, and head makai.'' CHARLES E. ROESSLER

snippet: Stephen Holden Critic's Notebook column on Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series at Lincoln Center; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN the founders of Palo Alto put their California dream together, Leland Stanford, the railroad magnate and politician, had just created a university on part of his huge horse farm across El Camino Real, the old Spanish mission road. The result, more than a century later, is a well-educated, diverse, creative community basking in the sunshine 40 miles south of San Francisco. The Palo Alto-Stanford synergy has produced, among other things, the entrepreneurs and skilled technicians who went on to build computer-industry giants like Hewlett-Packard and Sun Microsystems. Although the Silicon Valley boom has faded since the 1990's, you will still see clumps of computer engineers out for lunch on University Avenue, perhaps creating the next Internet. TOM and KATHE GIBBONEY

lead_paragraph: THE fear factor wasn't as high as the desperation factor. But then, on this reality show, nobody was going to have to eat bugs. On a pleasant Tuesday recently, a thousand souls hungry for something more complicated than lunch were lined up outside Commune, the defunct restaurant on East 22nd Street. They were there to be interviewed for jobs at a new place that would open in June and be featured in July on a reality show on NBC called ''The Restaurant.'' They came bearing résumés, glossies, candy and recommendations from chefs. Some had been waiting for hours.

lead_paragraph: Jim Kweskin is in the construction business. To be more precise, he's a partner in Fort Hill Construction, supervising projects in New York and Boston, where he lives. When he can, Mr. Kweskin likes to get together with friends to play music, often informally but sometimes in front of an audience. Tonight he will be appearing at Makor, a club on the Upper West Side. And he has a new CD out.
abstract: Jim Kweskin is in the construction business. To be more precise, he's a partner in Fort Hill Construction, supervising projects in New York and Boston, where he lives. When he can, Mr. Kweskin likes to get together with friends to play music, often informally but sometimes in front of an audience. Tonight he will be appearing at Makor, a club on the Upper West Side. And he has a new CD out.     None of this would be especially notable, except that, to a lot of people within shouting distance of his age, which is 62, Jim Kweskin qualifies as a household name. In the 1960's, the Jim Kweskin Jug Band loomed very large on the coffee-house circuit that nurtured the likes of Bob Dylan (who in even earlier days played with Mr. Kweskin), Joan Baez and Tom Rush. The rock historian Ed Ward went so far as to place the Kweskin Band alongside the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and the Byrds as that period's most influential groups. ''I'm perfecly serious,'' he said, in case anyone thought he wasn't.

lead_paragraph: SOME years ago, Al Hirschfeld returned home from a run-through of Ariel Dorfman's ''Death and the Maiden.'' His wife asked him what the play was about. ''Germany after the war,'' he said. The play was about Chile after dictatorship, but Hirschfeld had not been paying attention to the plot. He saw Gene Hackman onstage gagged and tied to a chair and assumed he was a captured Nazi. It didn't really matter anyway. Hirschfeld was too busy drawing what was happening onstage to notice.

lead_paragraph: The world's most widely grown genetically engineered crops -- soybeans, cotton and corn developed to be impervious to a popular herbicide -- are facing a new challenge to their continued long-term use. The herbicide, known as Roundup, is beginning to lose its effectiveness in controlling weeds.
abstract: Monsanto Corp's herbicide known as Roundup is beginning to lose its effectiveness in controlling weeds; weeds resistant to herbicide have emerged in Delaware, Maryland, California, western Tennessee and at edges of Corn Belt in Ohio and Indiana; crop scientists say problem is success of genetically engineered crops, especially soybeans, which account for more than three-quarters of all soybeans grown in US; farmers like genetically engineered crops, which are sold under brand name Roundup Ready, because they can spray Roundup herbicide directly over fields, killing weeds while leaving crops intact; popularity of crops has caused use of Roundup herbicide to skyrocket, setting up 'survival of the fittest' conditions in which rare weeks that survive herbicide can flourish; experts say eventually farmers will need to reduce their applications of genetically enegineered soybeans and other crops to preserve long-term usefulness; Roundup is Monsanto's biggest product, accounting for about 40 percent of its estimated revenue of $4.6 billion; photos (M)

snippet: Article on 36-hour visit to Taos, NM; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: TAOS, N. M., is viewed too often as a kind of Southwestern theme village. And it does have nice adobe. But it is also a vital, idiosyncratic community, where locals practice yoga and dirt biking and argue about a proposed Wal-Mart or snowboarding at Taos Ski Valley. This facet of the town, vivid and intriguing, is most in evidence now, in mid-winter, when the tourist traffic is light and the days are brisk. People stroll, the high-country snow sparkles, the air smells of burning pinyon and incense, and even the adobe seems unexpected and fresh. GRETCHEN REYNOLDS

Norman Norell, who was born Norman Levinson in Noblesville, Ind., owed much of his big-city panache to a star-struck youth. Manolo Blahnik, the son of banana growers, escaped the isolation of the Canary Islands by going to the cinema. John Weitz, whose bold life could have been a movie, married a Hollywood ingénue and fathered a pair of directors.
